title: Khvicha Kvaratskhelia , PSG Georgian artist whose football skills saved his father life
body_text:
As a boy, Khvicha Kvaratskhelia would sit and wait for the apples to grow.
Summers were spent in Tsalenjikha, his familyâ€™s hometown, cradled by Georgiaâ€™s Caucasus mountains. Between their house and the river was a green swathe, capped at one end by a wide iron gate. It was a perfect football pitch â€” but for one feature.

Since anybody recalled, the gate had been topped with decorative ornaments. Kvaratskehliaâ€™s father, Badri, a professional player himself, had countless footballs burst by its sharp metal. Remembering how he wept with every puncture, 30 years later he warned Khvicha, his second son.
Soon after, hearing the thump of ball on metal gate, Badri stepped outside to check if his message had been heeded. But something looked different.
Now, each spike was crowned by an apple. If a shot hit it? The ball would rebound harmlessly away. Each following June, Kvaratskhelia would repeat the ritual, plucking the early growers from the tree. He got through fewer balls than his father.
Badri, however, had a new problem: â€œThere would never be grass in the yard; because all day, all evening, Khvicha played.â€
Perhaps his sonâ€™s ingenuity was to be expected. Regional identity is important in Georgia â€” though he was mainly raised in the countryâ€™s capital, Tbilisi, Kvaratskheliaâ€™s family are Mingrelian, an ethnic group from the countryâ€™s west.
â€œPeople from Samegrelo are smart people,â€ says Badri. â€œVery smart people, and very creative. We are mountainous people and we behave like it. If we shake your hand, it is done â€” no signature needed. This is how you need to understand Khvicha, this is the culture in which he was cultivated.â€
And though Tsalenjikha has a population of just 25,000, its inhabitants have had an outsized influence on Georgian history. The elegiac Terenti Graneli was the nationâ€™s most significant poet for 800 years. Meliton Kantaria was the soldier who flew the Soviet flag over the Reichstag in 1945.
But before appearing for Paris Saint-Germain in the Champions League final, the fame of a 24-year-old winger may have eclipsed them all.
In the build-up to Europeâ€™s biggest game, The Athletic travelled to Tbilisi to discover how the remote footballing outpost of Georgia made Kvaratskhelia, including the concrete secrets of his dribbling, a lifeline at Dinamo Tbilisiâ€™s academy, and battered copies of Agatha Christie.

There is a homemade VHS tape in Kvaratskheliaâ€™s home in Tbilisi, made by his mother Maka. With Badri often away for his career â€” he played in Azerbaijan for several years, even winning three caps for the national team â€” Maka wanted her family to stay connected.
The cassette shows Badri playing for Azerbaijani club FK Shamkir in Champions League qualifying against Latvian side Skonto FC, where he scored a hat-trick. Kvaratskhelia would practise his fatherâ€™s free kicks, over and over again.
Ten years later, he repaid his father for the inspiration.
With Kvaratskhelia taking his first steps in professional football, Badri became dangerously ill. Doctors told him he needed to have emergency heart surgery but the family could not afford it.
Ultimately Kvaratskheliaâ€™s first salary at Lokomotiv Moscow, on increased terms, paid for the surgery that saved his fatherâ€™s life.
â€œIt wasnâ€™t even a question to him,â€ says Badri.
Badri will be at the Champions League final against Inter. At moments of high emotion, for his own heartâ€™s sake, he has to retreat into the familyâ€™s box. He was there, however, for Kvaratskheliaâ€™s greatest moment since signing for PSG in January: his goal against Aston Villa in the quarter-final.
At his quickest, Kvaratskhelia does not run but flows, changing direction like a stream through rapids. Villa centre-back Axel Disasi was taken underwater, foundering and falling. His shot was a knife thumping a message into the wall; this PSG side is a whole new force with Kvaratskhelia as its apex.

His parents had seen it before.
â€œOur first son is five years older,â€ says Maka. â€œAnd Khvicha wanted to be with his oldest brother all the time. But when he was five years old, we noticed the way he used to chase him. Khvicha would go straight, at such speed, and could turn 90 degrees, without changing pace.â€

â€œOnce, Khvicha was given a kimono as a present, and told to try judo,â€ remembers Badri. â€œItâ€™s such a quick sport â€” if you hesitate for a second, youâ€™re on the floor. The coach saw his reflexes, and straight away identified him as a sportsman.â€
And at Champions League level, dribbling is a form of combat. His first coaches marvelled at the rate of his quick, light touches, which at times look more like fencing than football. It is said that the great technicians fall in love with the ball first, the sport second. Kvaratskhelia was no different.
â€œWhen he started walking, he would walk with the ball,â€ says Maka. â€œWhen he went to sleep, he would sleep with the ball. There were lots of small concrete pitches in our neighbourhood. In the evenings, with Badri away, Iâ€™d search for him, looking in every playground, until Iâ€™d find him hundreds of metres away.
â€œBut you know, when he played as a little boy, he never played for fun. If he ever lost the ball, he sprinted back to defend the net, to help the goalie. I think that was why I knew heâ€™d be OK when he moved to Napoli.â€
It was in Italy, where he moved in 2022, that Kvaratskheliaâ€™s dribbling earned a continental reputation. Napoliâ€™s fans adored the straight-backed youngster, brow furrowed in concentration, who took smooth, delicate touches as if stroking a violin. First, he was Kvaradona, then he was Kvaravaggio. His art was made amid Tbilisiâ€™s brutalism.
â€œThese pitches were small, youâ€™re surrounded by six or seven players,â€ says Badri. â€œSo itâ€™s very hard to manoeuvre, you have to dribble like that. And then, if youâ€™re playing on the asphalt, you need to take care of yourself. You stay so upright because youâ€™ll get injured if you go down.â€
Tbilisi is a city of dappled light. Green shoots sprout from cracked concrete; its beauty comes from its untamed edges. Kvaratskheliaâ€™s face is emblazoned on billboards leading towards Sameba, the countryâ€™s largest and most famous cathedral. They advertise Georgian water, now a sponsor of PSG. For a country in the middle of political strife, he is something the population can rally behind.
Kvaratskhelia was spotted by Dinamo Tbilisi chief scout Temur Ugrekhelidze as a 10-year-old, playing at a tournament for neighbourhood children. Ugrekhelidze is the first man on many peopleâ€™s journey â€” from incoming Liverpool goalkeeper Giorgi Mamardashvili, to Saint-Etienne forward Zuriko Davitashvili, to Watford midfielder Giorgi Chakvetadze, all current internationals. Sitting in his office at Dinamoâ€™s academy, he pulls his cap over his eyes at the memory of Kvaratskhelia.

â€œIt was his courage,â€ he recollects. â€œThat was what stood out the most. Whenever he dribbled, he dribbled forward. There are lots of players who will try that once, lose the ball, and be afraid to do it again. But even if he lost the ball five times, heâ€™d try to take his player on, and go ahead.â€
Kvaratskheliaâ€™s first day at Dinamo came on the day that the club opened their new academy. Cristiano Ronaldo travelled from Real Madrid for the unveiling.
Years later, a photo from that day emerged after Georgia beat Portugal at last summerâ€™s European Championship â€” a pre-teen Kvaratskhelia, craning to be seen, posing alongside his hero.

As Georgiaâ€™s players sprinted to their fans after that 2-0 win, the most famous in the nationâ€™s history, Kvaratskhelia ran to commiserate with his hero.
â€œHe told him: â€˜Iâ€™m really sorry that we beat you,â€™â€ says Maka. â€œHe wanted to check that everything was OK, and there was no bad blood between them. And Ronaldo said: â€˜Good luck, I support you.â€™ Later, Ronaldo took himself into the Georgia changing room to give Khvicha his shirt.â€
But back in the Dinamo academy, another player was the star.
â€œKvara wasnâ€™t our strongest player in that period,â€ explains academy director Levan Gvantseladze. â€œZuriko Davitashvili was much better. Kvara always had these skills, but he was thin and underdeveloped, and because of that, he occasionally struggled.
â€œWe played some children in his team one year up â€” they were 2001 players who were playing with the 2000s. But Khvicha only ever played in his own age group, never the one above.â€
Instead, compared to his brothers, Kvaratskhelia grew slowly â€” his family believe that is one reason why he has avoided muscle injuries in his career, with his body getting gradually used to his frame.

He played as an orthodox right winger through the age groups, rather than his now customary left. With Dinamoâ€™s small-sided games lacking full-backs, the wide players were expected to cover back as well, developing their work rate. Gvantseladze thinks this helped develop his ability to cut inside off the left, as well as his defensive suitability for Luis Enriqueâ€™s system at PSG.
â€œAnother thing that actually helps him now is that we were the strongest team in Georgia,â€ Gvantseladze adds. â€œSo the opponents would drop deep, and the spaces in the final third would be very small. So the way you can beat that is with your creativity and aggressiveness, your one-on-one dribbling skills â€” and that carries through to PSG today.â€
â€œThere was another time, when he was a kid, that he had a fever, a very bad virus,â€ says Badri. â€œHe couldnâ€™t train for a month. But you know, for 14-year-old kids, thatâ€™s horrible. So they played against their biggest rival, Saburtalo, and he insisted on being on the bench. At the end of the first half, the Dinamo keeper got sent off. Then Khvicha came on, and bang: 3-0 to Dinamo, and all three goals from Khvicha.â€
Dinamoâ€™s coaches were becoming convinced, and normal rules were beginning to be waived.
The Kvaratskhelia family faced problems as Khvicha moved into the middle of his teens. They were struggling financially, with Badri needing to remain in Azerbaijan to find work, and Maka moving temporarily back to Tsalenjikha.
â€œWhen I was a kid in Georgia, my life was a little bit difficult,â€ Kvaratskhelia wrote of this period in The Playersâ€™ Tribune last year. â€œA little bit sometimes. No details here. But not always easy, you understand?â€
Maka used to give him small amounts of money to look after himself at tournaments. â€œBut heâ€™d never spend it!â€ she remembers. â€œHeâ€™d keep it, come back, and spend it on his brothers, or his friends, or take somebody else who was poor to eat at McDonaldâ€™s. He would always share.â€

Amid fears of how Kvaratskhelia would cope with the difficulties, his long-time youth coach, Vladimer Kakashvili, made a proposal.
â€œI was seeing a lot of problems in his life,â€ says Kakashvili, known to everybody as Lado. â€œThere was a rule that only players based outside Tbilisi could live and train at the academy full time. â€œThe guys that live here train twice a day,â€ explains Gvantseladze, from his office, one floor underneath the academy lodgings. â€œThey do individual training at 7am, then join up with the team later in the afternoon. In 2016, Dinamoâ€™s academy hosted the first Vitali Daraselia Cup, an international tournament for under-16 sides. Kvaratskhelia, then an under-15, was not slated to take part.
â€œAt the last minute, one of the teams who were set to take part pulled out,â€ remembers Gvantseladze. â€œIt was far too late for us to make any major changes. â€œIt was Khvichaâ€™s first real test against clubs from other countries â€” a year older than him as well â€” and he played so well that clubs from all over the world left with his name on their lips.â€
â€œHe was the revelation of the tournament,â€ says Lado.
Eight hundred years after Shota Rustaveli wrote The Knight in the Pantherâ€™s Skin, the definitive work of Georgian literature, the country had discovered a new chivalric hero. Kvaratskhelia would soon have more to share with his family. Within a year of his Vitali Daraselia Cup breakthrough, the slender winger made his Dinamo debut.
â€œUnderstand that a rose without thorns has never been plucked,â€ wrote Rustaveli.
â€œDid you know that Naples is like Georgia?â€ explains Badri, leaning back in his chair. â€œWe are both emotional people. Very emotional. We adore football. Itâ€™s not part of life: itâ€™s our life.â€

After Napoliâ€™s subsequent Serie A win this month, where he spent the first half of the season, Kvaratskhelia could still earn an unprecedented treble after moving to PSG: the Scudetto, the Ligue 1 title, and the Champions League.
â€œKhvicha had so much interest when he was leaving Dinamo Batumi,â€ says Badri. â€œBut when Napoli came inâ€¦ I told him, â€˜Youâ€™ll be playing where Maradona played, sharing the same stadium, changing in the same dressing room. Just sign the contract â€” go!â€™â€

â€œHe came up after the game and told me that he was too ashamed to ask for the jersey,â€ Badri remembers. â€œIt was only when they played the away leg in Liverpool that Virgil actually called him over himself, and asked if they could trade.â€
â€œHonestly, he has no life outside of football,â€ says Maka, before describing one exception. On team trips, Kvaratskhelia can often be found reading paperbacks, face screwed in concentration like heâ€™s playing â€” reading detective fiction. Agatha Christie is his favourite.

â€œI wanted him to celebrate more,â€ she says. â€œAnd so I asked him: â€˜Why didnâ€™t you celebrate like your team-mates?â€™ And he replied: â€˜Mother, there is nothing to celebrate yet. We still have a final to play.â€™â€
The under-16s are warming up on the far pitch at Dinamo Tbilisiâ€™s academy. Seventy-four per cent of Georgiaâ€™s senior national team were produced here, along with 60 per cent of the under-21s, and 67 per cent of the under-19s.

But even amid a forest of low socks, one player bears more of a resemblance to Dinamoâ€™s star graduate than others. Tornike Kvaratskhelia is 15, a tall, slender winger like his brother.
